body.p:
I regret to add Dr's Statement is false in many
respects, as probably his information was
derived from Mr Goldsmith.

In the first place the Doctor is not
legally our Rabbi, he never was so elected.

In the second, Dr E never questioned
messenger but merely listened to calumny

In the third, he had no recourse
to any expedient. The Trustees did so
authorise him to appear before the three
members without Mr Messinger being
aware of their action.

In the fourth. The congregation have
adopted to eat meat of no other shochet
than Messinger & we boast as religious
men as any in the world, perhaps not
more so.

There will be a sequel to this of
which I shall keep you advised.

Upon these remarks you may be
certain Dr E. cannot be reelected at
the end of the year & if you know of any
competent ministers who of their own accord
or at your suggestion will visit San
Francisco & when here will act prudently
they would do well to come out
yrs. Truly. H I Labatt

they intend to request the Doctor to
resign. He who was so unpopular
& was elected by such a struggle &
such sacrifices has in 6 short weeks
make himself outrageously inimical
to the whole congregation. I hear but
two opinions. One asking him to resign
the other dismissing him from his post.

In a new country it was in
the Doctors province to endear himself
to a warm & ardent congregation but
he has chosen the opposite. Yesterday
in conversation the Doctor was advised
by my father & myself to be careful
of his actions that the congregation were very
uneasy about the Schochet matter & his
position & might censure him. He said
on that subject he courted their censure
& forthwith proclaimed to the world through
the papers that we were all fools & knew
not what we did that our Shochet
was no shochet & his Shechilah to be
Terephah. (see publication)

I enclose you the publication with
the notes thereupon that seem proper.
I regret this matter on the Doctor's account

NOTICE TO THE ISRAELITES OF
SAN FRANCISCO AND VICINITY.

p.hi:
To the Officers of the Congregations Emanuel and Shereth
Israel, and to the Members of the Jewish Denomination
of this City:

body.p:
BRETHREN IN FAITH!—In reply to certain queries
laid before me by the Prest. of K. K. Sh. Js., in a letter
dated Nov. 29, A. C., I feel conscientiously bound to
state at large:

2d. They were strictly adhered to by our Prophets:
See Ezek. 4: 14; Dan. 1: 8; and by our nation through
a series of ages and generations.

These laws are preservative of physical and mental
health. By abstaining from the use of gross blood, (the
cruor) from certain portions of (almost) indigestible fat, from animals that feed on carrion, that die of themselves,
that labor under consumptive, hepatic, hydrocephalous
diseases, or of those of the kidneys, the heart, or the
other internal organs—not to mention the loathsome
disease of the swine—by abstaining from these, we reject
food that is a prolific source of disease, that blunts the
moral feelings, that inflames the passions, irritates the
blood, and rouses the animal propensities—that animal-
izes man.

This fact is acknowledged by the testimony of ages
past, and by the light of advanced science of the present
age, as also by Christian commentators: See Clarke and
other commentators on Lev. 11 et Deut. 14.

We therefore need not wonder that men of science and
intelligence, as also proprietors of public establishments
of note even of other denominations, in places where we
and our principles are known, never use common animal
food whenever such as prepared for our use is within
reach.*

And in all Israel, from times immemorial, only men of
gravity, of unquestionable piety, and approved solidity
of character and principle, were entrusted with the
office of Shochat, i. e. of killing and inspecting the ani-
mals intended for the use of Israelites, who, on finding
the animal free from disease and sound, generally puts
a seal used solely for that purpose on different portions
of it, as marks of its properiety for our use.

The Schochat acts under the inspection of the Rabbi.
The former after a proper study of Animal Anatomy and
Pathology, as laid down in our laws, has to submit to an
examination to a properly authorized Rabbi, (usually
that of the respective city where the Schochat wishes to
practice,) who, on finding the candidate religiously and
legally trustworthy, provides him with a Rabbalah, (au-
thorization to be a Shochat,) and even then the Shochat
has to refer to the Rabbi certain difficult cases, and to
submit to re-examination at certain periods.

Only a diplomated Rabbi is authorized by our law to
institute a Schochat; no Schochat nor a number of Scho-
chalim dare presume to do so, such an act is by the law
delared null; and the person thus created Shochat is de-
clare by said laws an interloper, and unworthy of trust.
(Code Yorah Deah §1 let. 18, et. ib. Tor Zahab lit 4.)

There are cases in which even legally instituted
Shochlim forfeit their Rabbalah. Among others we may
mention the following, as pertinent to the subject.

1. If a Shochat is found to have himself shown a dis-
regard towards the dietetic laws by partaking of for-
bidden food. (Code Y. D., § §1, 2, 119 etc.)

2. If he violates the Sabbath or other national
laws. (Ib.)

3. By physical causes, as obtuseness of the senses
dim, or short sightedness.

4. Besides, no Shochat is to be trusted if he is inter
ested in the result of his decision. (Ib. §2 Tor Zahat
ad. lit. 18.)

Whereas, I learn that an individual practises here as
Shochat—and, whereas, a sacred duty imposes upon me
the hard task—and the letter of the President of K. K.
Sh. Is. requires me to declare whether said individual is
a legal Shochat, I feel obliged to state, that of five candi-
dates who since my stay here, (July 1st, A. C.,) presented
themselves to me for authorization or examination, only
two were found worthy of trust, viz:—Mr. Isaac Gold-
smith, the Shochat of this city, and Mr. Borier of Sacra-
mento city, and they were examined accordingly; the
other three were rejected for obvious reasons. Among
the latter is the young man in question.

He was recommeaded to me for examination, and was
rejected on the ground of his falling under cases 1, 2, 3, 4,
state above as disqualifications for said office. He is
known to have forfeited his ?
even since his few months' stay in this State.

Thus rejected by our Law, he had recourse to the fol-
lowing expedient. He applied for authorization for three
persons who formerly are said to have acted as Shochin.
But as two of them publicly work in stores on the Sab-
bath and Holydays, and the third is known——.

I deeply and sincerely lament to be in duty bound to
declare said expedient illegal; and—in the name of our
ancient and venerable Laws in Codes Yorch Deah § §
1, 2, 119, 254; Moshen Mishpat, §34; Ebenezer, §123;
Maimonides Hilch; Gereshen Cap. 3, §15, et alibi—said
young man to be no Shochat; and his Shechilah to be
Terephah.

“He that doeth keep his soul will keep far from
them.”—Prov. 22:5.

In bringing this to the notice of the scrupulous Israel-
ites of this city and vicinity, I sign
Faithfully and humbly,
JULIUS ECKMAN, Rabbi.
San Francisco, Dec. 19, (5615) 1854.

market prices, at Messrs. Miller's, Pacific, near Kearny
